job_title: NICU RN III in Madera, CA
pros: They will train you in the NICU as a new grad.. they love new grads
cons: The NICU can be clicky. You will move up quickly if you are friends with the right people. Their rn retention is not the best... There is high turn over. Lots of rns will start out here and get a year or two in and then get a job in the bay area where they pay a lot more. There aren't many incentives to stay and the hospital seems totally fine with the high turn over. The overall inexperienced staff in the Nicu is a little scary and definitely unsafe especially when the census is high since it's harder to watch what the inexperienced staff/floats/or travelers are doing. Lots of floats and travelers during times if high census.

review_title: It's the people that make this hospital a great place to work, certainly not the administration
job_title: Certified Pediatric Nurse Practitioner in Madera, CA
pros:
Everyone works together towards one objective -taking care of the children.
Until recently, the retention rate was impressive - everyone who works at Children's are mostly family. Physicians and staff work together well, minimal hierarchy - with the exception of the administrators - of which there are too many.
Children's was a fabulous place to work years ago, but they are more focused on being a business, growing rapidly
cons: Too worried about monopolizing the Pediatric healthcare market in the Central Valley. Continue to build facilities which are poorly staffed - forgetting their flagship hospital. Resources are strapped, not enough staff, the staff that are there are not paid anywhere near what other hospitals in the area are paying. I suspect they are going to have a hard time attracting physicians and staff to Madera if they don't fix these issues. This is truly a shame, because the work, the care offered by the staff at Children's is what has brought Children's to this point - not the buildings scattered all over the Central Valley, not the administrators.

pros: nice environment, patients and family

pros: The idea of the hospital, the mission and all that is excellent. The employees smile and greet each other in the hallways, it makes it feel like a second home sometimes. The organization as a whole is good, there is a positive flow to get more kids taken care of, to help more people. You get called to this work to help kids and families and that’s what they do here.
cons:
Management is...difficult. They hire from within, which is great until you get a charge who is besties with this and that person so they get away with murder and then you get called out on the very same thing. I wish it was an isolated issue, but it isn’t. There is very little recourse and basically the attitude is “don’t like it, leave” which is not at all the supportive, open-door policy management they tell you they have when you get hired. 
Also, the don’t have to pay as well as the other area hospitals because they have the kid pull, you work here because you want to help kids not for the money. 
Finally, upward mobility is really slow and limited. The list of things to achieve/maintain RN 2 or 3 status is the most extensive I’ve seen.

pros: Valley Children's Healthcare has an excellent reputation in the community for offering quality pediatric healthcare.  I am proud to have been an employee of this organization for 23 years as the Director of Clinical Laboratories and for 3 years as the Director of Children's Home Care.  The staff of the hospital and Children's Home Care were dedicated to serving the interests of children's health in the Central Valley.  Hospital Leadership provided substantial support to the Home Care division, allowing for both expansion of current services and addition of new services.  I would highly recommend this employer to those looking for a career in the pediatric healthcare field.
cons: Children's Home Care is located off-site from the main hospital campus.  Although advantageous for patients living within the Fresno city limits, it is somewhat more difficult for Home Care management to attend regular hospital, on-site meetings.

job_title: IT Applications Coordinator in Fresno, CA
pros: Valley Children's is one of the best places to work, as it has a great culture and the people are phenomenal. Its also give you an opportunity to strike a great balance between work and life. And very much encouraged by the leadership, you also have the opportunity to grow your skills and moved vertically within the organization and the HR team does a great job keeping track of the talent with the organization. Definitely, recommend Valley Children's if you're looking to be part of something that helps the community, as well as grows your career.
cons: I have seen any so far in the time I have been here.

review_title: Great Bedside Team.  Executive Team disconnected.
pros: It is truly a family environment.  Staff care for each other and that is seen in their interactions.  The staff have an incredible talent for caring for children as if they were their own.  They truly have a "calling" as pediatric care givers.  Physicians and Nursing Leadership work well together and support each other.  The quality of care is incredible!
cons:
Executive leadership is disconnected with bedside care teams.  
Executive team is more concerned with making the U.S. News list and the appearance of their new buildings and financial performance before any thought to care being delivered.  The bedside team and middle management have the drive and motivation but lack the resources to do their very best because of a severe lack of resources at the main campus.   Executives continue to create top level positions, while bedside staff go without basic resources to provide the best care possible.   It's more important to have state of the art glass in a new building and new grass for the Harvest Ball than to have  enough staff and the right equipment to care for kids.  Executive leadership blames and shames the teams that are actually doing the work of caring for kids.

review_title: It’s a great place to start, not a great place to advance in your career.
pros: It’s a great place to get pediatric experience as a nurse. Pediatric care is so hard to come by in the Valley, it’s also great specialized care. You work with people who really care about their jobs and their patients!
cons: The company has changed so much. I spent over half a decade here. I’ve ran into people who have left and felt the same lack of appreciation by the organization. The pay is not competitive and to be honest after years of working and getting paid a few dollars more than a new grad, you just don’t want to work as hard. They give staff zero motivation to move forward. There’s also no opportunities to advance. People aren’t retiring, there is a bit of favoritism and people can be petty. There are people who talk down to peers or continuously violate policies and they don’t get penalized for it. You just get tired of watching people get away with things. I’ve also had a coworker say the CEO once say something along the lines like, “there’s plenty of nurses lined up out there to take new positions”. I left and it’s been the best experience for me. I got a five figure sign on bonus at another competitive hospital in the area, competitive pay, great affordable benefits, discounts for my meals (plus amazing food!)... little things of course but it means so much when you go without it for so long! Overall, it’s a great place to start but after a year or two it’s time to just move on. I wish I would’ve left sooner, but I loved working with kids and I loved my patients. It’s hard to not get emotionally attached. This facility just lacks employee recognition, support and appreciation. Their idea of appreciation is handing out left over cafeteria lunch boxes that will give your coworker the runs (true story). Not to mention the number of times they’ve floated nurses to unsafe areas and placed patients at risk. They’d rather have a body to do the job than a competent person doing the job. There’s so much that happens here behind closed doors and there’s lack of accountability. They’d rather hush things up than face them head on. They’re so focused on community expansion and outreach that they’re failing to provide their healthcare workers with the resources they need like adequate staffing, computers that work, enough interpreters... the list just goes on.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Madera, CA
pros: Good working environment with everyone being very friendly and willing to help, fair nurse:patient ratios
cons: Pay is less than many other hospitals in the area, with infrequent pay raises. Clinical ladder makes it more difficult to advance to RN 2 and requires multiple steps.

Executive leadership blames and shames the teams that are actually doing the work of caring for kids.

review_title: It’s a great place to start, not a great place to advance in your career.
pros: It’s a great place to get pediatric experience as a nurse. Pediatric care is so hard to come by in the Valley, it’s also great specialized care. You work with people who really care about their jobs and their patients!
cons: The company has changed so much. I spent over half a decade here. I’ve ran into people who have left and felt the same lack of appreciation by the organization. The pay is not competitive and to be honest after years of working and getting paid a few dollars more than a new grad, you just don’t want to work as hard. They give staff zero motivation to move forward. There’s also no opportunities to advance. People aren’t retiring, there is a bit of favoritism and people can be petty. There are people who talk down to peers or continuously violate policies and they don’t get penalized for it. You just get tired of watching people get away with things. I’ve also had a coworker say the CEO once say something along the lines like, “there’s plenty of nurses lined up out there to take new positions”. I left and it’s been the best experience for me. I got a five figure sign on bonus at another competitive hospital in the area, competitive pay, great affordable benefits, discounts for my meals (plus amazing food!)... little things of course but it means so much when you go without it for so long! Overall, it’s a great place to start but after a year or two it’s time to just move on. I wish I would’ve left sooner, but I loved working with kids and I loved my patients. It’s hard to not get emotionally attached. This facility just lacks employee recognition, support and appreciation. Their idea of appreciation is handing out left over cafeteria lunch boxes that will give your coworker the runs (true story). Not to mention the number of times they’ve floated nurses to unsafe areas and placed patients at risk. They’d rather have a body to do the job than a competent person doing the job. There’s so much that happens here behind closed doors and there’s lack of accountability. They’d rather hush things up than face them head on. They’re so focused on community expansion and outreach that they’re failing to provide their healthcare workers with the resources they need like adequate staffing, computers that work, enough interpreters... the list just goes on.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Madera, CA
pros: Good working environment with everyone being very friendly and willing to help, fair nurse:patient ratios
cons: Pay is less than many other hospitals in the area, with infrequent pay raises. Clinical ladder makes it more difficult to advance to RN 2 and requires multiple steps.

pros: Community based pediatric care facility with strong reputation and desire to provide quality care to their pediatric patients.
cons: Lack of buy into organization vision; extensive heirchy which is top heavy. Difficult to make progress toward positive changes.

pros: Helping kids is a great thing. Great RN's who really truly care about the kids.
cons: The hospital is focusing too much on expanding in the valley and are losing sight of what the hospital was originally there to do.
